climbs.name: The Shortest Straw
climbs.fa: Matt Samet, Lee Sheftel, Cameron Burns

content.description: Climb jugs to a roof.  Clip the second bolt off of an undercling sidepull.  Move left into the crux.  This involves a series of crimps to a large jug next to the third bolt.  Finally, move right over the buldge and clip the fourth while you make your way to the chains.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a two bolt anchor
content.location: Same start as Last Straw, but move left instead of right.

content.description: Stick clip the high first bolt.  There is a block on the left side of the first bolt that is a bit loose.  Make easy but steep moves through the second clip.  You then enter the crux which involves going to a right hand gaston off of a small left under cling.  Clip the third off of a  blind left hand side-pull.  Finally, pull the bulge and the business is over.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Far right side of damage wall.

climbs.name: Physical Therapy
climbs.fa: Kirk Miller, Kevin Gabaldon (per Samet & Jett guide)

content.description: Climb up the horizontal breaks in the rock on large holds to the two foot roof. Pull the roof and crimp your way to the top.
content.protection: 4 bolts + two bolt anchor with chains
content.location: About 30 feet from the left side of Damage Wall. Look for the SMC hanger on the second bolt just below the roof. There is also a vertical seam directly above the roof.

content.description: A variation to the Shortest Straw, with one bolt to the right side of the big nugget half way up.
content.protection: 4 bolts to two bolt anchor with chains

content.description:
When I stumbled onto this canyon in the 1980's it was un-touched.  Because I'd moved close to the nearby town of Chilili, I started climbing there with anyone I could talk into visiting.   The first round of development was completed with help from many friends, including Johnny Myrick, Randall Jet, Spike, and Matt Samet. 

  This route was one of the first to go.
content.protection: 2 bolts to an anchor with lowering hardware

content.description: Stick clip the high first bolt, or take your chances on the choss below.
content.protection: 3 bolts to two bolt anchor with chains
content.location: Near the middle of Damage Wall, to the left of the large nugget half way up that marks the two variations of the Straw routes.

climbs.name: Brain Damage
climbs.fa: Dennis Zallen, John Lewis, Linda Isler

content.description: Pulling the small roof is the crux and felt difficult for the grade. Thin climbing above the roof to the anchors. Staying left above the roof is supposedly 5.9 climbing.
content.location: Walk left at the top of the access trail. The route is 35 feet to the left of the first roof you pass.

content.description: Climb up onto the ledge. The earlier you take to the face on the left, the harder the climbing. The arete on the right side is pretty mellow.
content.protection: 4 bolts + two bolt anchor with chains
content.location: Just to the right of the large tree at the left end of Damage Wall. Brain Damage is the route to the right that starts with a small arching roof (less than a foot deep).

content.description: The climbing on the face is fairly straightforward, but the bolts are spaced pretty far and the rock has several ledges that stick out so climb carefully.
content.protection: 3 bolts to two bold anchor with chains.
content.location: Right in front of the large pine tree at the left end of Damage Wall

content.description: The climbing at Damage Wall is mostly dead vertical with occasional small roofs (1-2feet deep) about half way up. The holds are mostly crimps and the rock texture is more forgiving on the skin than some of the other areas at New Canyon. The routes offer challenging sequences of powerful moves, but not as continuously strenuous like the Power Wall routes.   The Damage Wall has 9 routes. From right to left. Make sure to check for anchors before you start up climbs.
